comment.author: 11953092@N04
comment._content: He actually transferred from the Bedfordshire Regiment to the Cambridge Regiment in 1917. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29613/pages/5641 He retired in 1920 www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/32080/supplements/9884

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Captain Percy Edward Bass, Cambridgeshire Regiment, resigned his commission on 12 Oct 1920.  London Gazette 32080.  His medal card 1914-1920 is held by the National Archive WO 327/2.//

comment.author: 7332792@N03
comment._content:
I read every one as they come up, always hoping they might have been one of the lucky ones....

My Great Uncle, Sergeant Charles Charter was in the 1st Battalion, Cambridgeshire Regiment.  He was killed in action 18/9/1918.  I couldn't help but wonder if this officer may have ever come across Charlie.....

I would also like to compliment the researchers who give so much time to finding the stories of these men.... It makes so much difference to know who they were.  Thank you.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: You're absolutely right, Anna, the work that has been done is fantastic and some really interesting pieces of information have been found. We're very grateful to all who've contributed.

comment.author: 77613909@N05
comment._content:
Posted to Western Front 22-12-17, joining 1/1st btn Cambridgeshire Regiment 3(5?)-1-18. Gassed 8-3-18, to England 27-3-18, wounded. Remained in UK until discharge.

Cliff Brown

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
National Probate record shows he died at Invergourie, Oving, Buckinghamshire on 4th Jun 1937. Probate was granted to his widow, Margaret Murray Bass. £2171 0s 6d.

At the time of the 1911 census they had been living at Strathmore, Longley Road, Wealdstone, Middlesex and Percy was a Commercial Clerk for the Port of London Authority. They had been married for 3 years and had no children.
